guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for clozapine and CYP1A2

history.description: Annotation current with May 2021 DPWG Guideline release

literature.title: Dutch Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) guideline for the gene-drug interaction between CYP2D6, CYP3A4 and CYP1A2 and antipsychotics.

relatedGenes.name: cytochrome P450 family 1 subfamily A member 2

summaryMarkdown.html: There is no gene-drug interaction between CYP1A2 and clozapine.

textMarkdown.html:
Dutch Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) guideline for the gene-drug interaction between CYP2D6, CYP3A4 and CYP1A2 and antipsychotics. European journal of human genetics (2023)

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group published a paper with the guidelines for clozapine and CYP1A2 as per the February 2022 guidelines and further details on the assessed literature [Article:37002327]. Supplementary Table 12A: "Suggested clinical decision support texts for health care professionals for CYP1A2-clozapine" states for CYP1A2 genotype or phenotype - clozapine pairs "This is NOT a gene-drug interaction.".

February 2022 Update

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) has updated their recommendations for clozapine based on CYP1A2 genotype. They now conclude there is no gene-drug interaction between any CYP1A2 alleles and clozapine. As a result, all recommendation have been removed. See the DPWG February 2022 update.

May 2021 Guideline

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) has evaluated therapeutic dose recommendations for clozapine based on CYP1A2 genotype. They recommend adjusting clozapine dose as a function of clozapine plasma concentrations in patients with one or two copies of the CYP1A2*1C allele.

Wording in table taken from the Dutch guidelines August 2019 update.

Allele/Genotype/Phenotype Drug Description Recommendation
CYP1A2 NM clozapine This is NOT a gene-drug interaction N/A
CYP1A2 IM clozapine This is NOT a gene-drug interaction N/A
CYP1A2 PM clozapine This is NOT a gene-drug interaction N/A
CYP1A2*1A/*1F clozapine This is NOT a gene-drug interaction N/A
CYP1A2*1C-heterozygote clozapine The genetic polymorphism can result in a reduced metabolism of clozapine. This can result in an increase in the plasma concentration of clozapine and thereby the risk of adverse events. It is not possible to offer substantiated advice for dose reduction based on the literature.
1. Adjust the dose as a function of the plasma concentration of clozapine. A therapeutic range of 200-600 ng/mL has been proposed for clozapine.
CYP1A2*1C/*1C clozapine The genetic polymorphism can result in a reduced metabolism of clozapine. This can result in an increase in the plasma concentration of clozapine and thereby the risk of adverse events. It is not possible to offer substantiated advice for dose reduction based on the literature.
1. Adjust the dose as a function of the plasma concentration of clozapine. A therapeutic range of 200-600 ng/mL has been proposed for clozapine.

Read for more information about this recommendation, Read about gene information from DPWG
